M.G.L. c. 186, \u00a714.proposition: *(Breach of Covenant of Quiet Enjoyment – M.G.L. c. 186, §14)*

G.L. c. 223, \u00a72.proposition: Venue is proper in the Brockton Division of the District Court Department pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §2 because the real property that is the subject of this action is located in Plymouth County, and Defendant conducts business there.

G.L. c. 185C, \u00a73.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper under G.L. c. 185C, §3 and the general jurisdiction of the District Court for actions concerning residential tenancies and claims under G.L. c. 186, §14.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a714.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper under G.L. c. 185C, §3 and the general jurisdiction of the District Court for actions concerning residential tenancies and claims under G.L. c. 186, §14.

Massachusetts General Laws c. 186, \u00a.proposition: Under Massachusetts General Laws c. 186, §14, a landlord shall not directly or indirectly interfere with the quiet enjoyment of the leased premises by the tenant.

G.L. c. 111, \u00a7127A.proposition: The provision of hot water is a minimum standard of habitability required under G.L. c. 111, §127A and the State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.190, which mandates that landlords supply hot water of at least 110°F.

105 C.M.R. 410.190.proposition: The provision of hot water is a minimum standard of habitability required under G.L. c. 111, §127A and the State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.190, which mandates that landlords supply hot water of at least 110°F.

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in every residential tenancy in Massachusetts.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The opinion assumes the existence of an implied covenant (or warranty) of quiet enjoyment and analyzes whether the landlords breached it via constructive eviction, but it does not clearly state that such a covenant is implied in every residential tenancy in Massachusetts. The court’s discussion is focused on the scope of the landlord’s responsibility for noise from a commercial tenant, not on defining the universal applicability of the covenant to all residential leases. Thus, while consistent with that proposition, the case does not expressly establish it as a general rule.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: The landlords argue that they did not violate the tenants’ implied covenant of quiet enjoyment because they are not chargeable with the noise from the lounge. The landlords do not challenge the judge’s conclusion that the noise emanating from the lounge was sufficient to constitute a constructive eviction, if that noise could be attributed to the landlords.

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in every residential tenancy in Massachusetts.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that every tenancy includes an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb the tenant’s quiet enjoyment. This is said in the context of residential premises and is tied to G.L. c. 186, § 14 and Massachusetts landlord-tenant law, so it is proper authority for the proposition that the covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in every residential tenancy in Massachusetts.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy … Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy.  Id.”

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).proposition: The failure to provide essential services such as heat or hot water constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the standard of fault (at least negligence with notice) required for a landlord to be liable under the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment, using prior cases as examples (such as failures to repair defects). It does not address heat, hot water, or other essential services, and therefore does not establish that failure to provide such services constitutes a breach. The case is about lead paint liability and the interaction between the lead paint statute and G.L. c. 186, § 14, not essential services like heat or hot water.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).relevant_excerpt: “We noted that a landlord’s failure ‘to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.’ See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so).”

McAllister v. Boston Housing Auth., 429.raw_text: McAllister v. Boston Housing Auth., 429 Mass. 300 (1999)
McAllister v. Boston Housing Auth., 429.proposition: The failure to provide essential services such as heat or hot water constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
McAllister v. Boston Housing Auth., 429.support_reasoning: This case concerns a slip-and-fall on exterior ice and addresses negligence, the covenant of quiet enjoyment, and the implied warranty of habitability in that context. The discussion of habitability cites other cases where lack of heat and hot water were among substantial code violations, but McAllister itself does not hold or state that failure to provide heat or hot water constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. It therefore does not provide direct authority for the specific proposition stated.
McAllister v. Boston Housing Auth., 429.relevant_excerpt: The implied warranty of habitability "is concerned with the provision, maintenance, and repair of the physical facilities vital to the use of the leased premises" (emphasis in original). Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 282 (1994). Not every breach of the State sanitary code supports a claim under the implied warranty of habitability. Rather, the implied warranty of habitability applies to significant defects in the property itself. Berman & Sons v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196, 201-202 (1979) ("A dwelling afflicted with a substantial Sanitary Code violation is not habitable"). See, e.g., Cruz Mgt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782, 787 (1994) (apartment lacked adequate heat, hot water, and fire escape...).

Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.raw_text: Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987)
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.proposition: The failure to provide essential services such as heat or hot water constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the landlord’s regulatory duty under the State Sanitary Code to provide heat and hot water and holds that this obligation cannot be shifted to the tenant absent a written agreement. However, the case does not analyze or decide whether failure to provide heat or hot water constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment; its treatment of heat and hot water arises in the context of sanitary code compliance and enforceability of an oral agreement, not quiet enjoyment. Therefore it does not support the specific proposition claimed.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.relevant_excerpt: “The tenant maintains that under the State Sanitary Code the landlord is not excused from his obligation to provide heat and hot water unless there is a writing transferring the obligation to the tenant. The State Sanitary Code, 105 Code Mass. Regs. §§ 410.190 and 410.201 (1983), provides that the owner of a dwelling ‘shall’ supply heat and hot water ‘except and to the extent that the occupant is required to supply the fuel under a written letting agreement.’… The plain and unambiguous language of the regulation indicates that a writing is required when the obligation to provide heat and hot water is transferred to the tenant.”}

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982)
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that a landlord’s inaction or delay in remedying conditions that materially impair the tenant’s use of the premises can constitute interference “by omission” under G.L. c. 186, §14.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The case clearly holds that a landlord’s failure to provide heat, regardless of financial inability or intent, constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and a violation of G.L. c. 186, §14. However, the opinion frames this in terms of the landlord’s “failure to provide heat” as actionable conduct; it does not expressly discuss or characterize the violation as “interference by omission” or analyze delay/inaction as a distinct doctrinal category. While one could infer that nonfeasance constitutes actionable interference, the case does not explicitly articulate the ‘by omission’ formulation stated in the proposition.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: “The tenant correctly argues that the judge erred in declaring that the landlords’ financial inability to purchase oil constituted a defense to the quiet enjoyment claim. A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season… constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment… It is not necessary to recovery that the landlord intended to violate the covenant. Rather ‘the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.’… liability will be imposed ‘whenever the “natural and probable consequence” of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.’”

Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.proposition: The implied covenant ensures tenants the right to occupy premises suitable for human habitation.
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.support_reasoning: The court expressly limits the implied warranty (covenant) of habitability to the physical condition of the premises and rejects the argument that it requires provision of security or protection from criminal activity. It holds that the warranty concerns physical facilities vital to residential use, not broader safety or social conditions. Thus, the case does not state that the implied covenant ensures tenants a right to premises suitable for human habitation in the broader, security-based sense asserted in the proposition, and in fact narrows that concept.
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “We adopted the rule that in all rentals of premises for dwelling purposes, there is implied a warranty that the premises are fit for human occupation. … Under this warranty of habitability, the landlord warrants ‘that at the inception of the rental there are no latent [or patent] defects in facilities vital to the use of the premises for residential purposes and that these essential facilities will remain during the entire term in a condition which makes the property livable.’ … We conclude that the implied warranty of habitability is concerned with the provision, maintenance, and repair of the physical facilities vital to the use of the leased premises, and is not breached solely by the presence on the premises of uninvited persons engaged in unlawful activities or by the failure to provide security services.”

Fletcher v. Chamberlin, 171 Mass. 135 (1.proposition: Defendant’s failure to comply with this obligation resulted in a continuing, substantial interference with Plaintiff’s ability to live peaceably in her apartment.
Fletcher v. Chamberlin, 171 Mass. 135 (1.case_name: New England Railroad v. Board of Railroad Commissioners
Fletcher v. Chamberlin, 171 Mass. 135 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion addresses statutory authority for altering a railroad-highway crossing and whether widening a way is a permissible change in location under the statute. It does not involve a landlord‑tenant relationship, habitability, or any issue of interference with a tenant’s ability to live peaceably in an apartment. Therefore, it does not support the proposition about a defendant’s failure causing a continuing, substantial interference with a plaintiff’s residential use.
Fletcher v. Chamberlin, 171 Mass. 135 (1.relevant_excerpt: "The plain purpose of Pub. Sts. c. 112, § 129, is to give a method of making any alteration in the crossing of a railroad and a way for ordinary travel which may be necessary for either the safety or the convenience of the public. The alteration may be in the crossing itself, in the approaches thereto, or in the location of the railroad or the way for ordinary travel."

Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.raw_text: Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771 (1994)
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.proposition: Defendant’s failure to comply with this obligation resulted in a continuing, substantial interference with Plaintiff’s ability to live peaceably in her apartment.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses serious, ongoing defects in the tenant’s apartment (rodent and cockroach infestation, inadequate heat, other serious deficiencies) and notes that the tenant vacated because of the conditions, but the legal issue actually decided concerns the *measure of damages* for breach of the implied warranty of habitability in subsidized housing. The court expressly declined to award separate quiet enjoyment damages to avoid duplication and did not frame its holding in terms of a "continuing, substantial interference" with the tenant’s ability to live peaceably. Thus, while the facts describe severe interference, the case is not used as authority for that specific legal proposition.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.relevant_excerpt: Wideman’s tenancy with Cruz Management commenced on or about May 18, 1988. She vacated her apartment, located at 228 Magnolia Street, in the Dorchester section of Boston, some time in October, 1990. During her tenancy, she and her two sons endured continuing infestations of rodents and cockroaches. Heat in the apartment ranged from nonexistent (at worst) to insufficient (at best). Cruz Management had notice of these defects, as well as others, which the judge found existed… Most of the violations remained uncorrected through October, 1990, when Wideman finally vacated.
